dialogues.text: INT. LIPPESTAD’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 127 LIPPESTAD enters. SIGNE is asleep in front of the TV. New reports of race crimes across the country. He checks on REBEKAH. He changes her oxygen tank. Lifts h into a more comfortable position. The phone goes. He crosses the landing. Answers.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: You fucking Nazi lover. I know where you live. I’m going to make sure you and your family rot in hell.
The line cuts. Lippestad comes back down to the lounge. A furtive look o the window. As from the TV we hear: Anger engulfing the nation.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (gently wakes Signe) Hey... Come on, I’1ll take you up. As she gets up:

dialogues.speaker: SIGNE
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Just the office.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNE
dialogues.text: That’s the third one tonight. See LIPPESTAD.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Don’t answer the phone anymore. And keep the children inside. I‘’1l ask the police to watch the house. Just for the moment. While people are angry.

dialogues.speaker: GJORV
dialogues.text: (leaving PM's residency) I have just met with the Prime Minister. He has asked me to conduct a searching and independent inquiry into the attacks on 22 July. I have accepted and our work will begin immediately. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PM’S RESIDENCY - SAME TIME 128A The PM in his hallway addresses the Press. a

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: This inquiry is of vital importance. Whatever went wrong we must confront it. If we fail to do so, the terrorist will surely win. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD opposite BREIVIK. a

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: My recommendation is that you plead insanity. You will be assessed by psychiatrists. The court will decide whether to accept their diagnosis. If they do, you’ll go to hospital for treatment. Not jail.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: People will be very angry.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: It’s the law.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Will I be able to address the court?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: You will have the same rights as any other defendant.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Okay. We’re decided then. He goes to the door, presses a button to be let out.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Geir, are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: You see why I chose you. a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131 132 70. See LIPPESTAD. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD spits into a sink. Nauseous. Looks at himself i the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S ICU ROOM - MIDDLE OF NIG VILJAR unconscious. The soft bleep of intensive care machines. CHRISTIN fitfully sleeping. SVEINN too. A sleeping TORJE his lap. Angle on VILJAR’S hand. A slight movement. Then movement his left eye. A machine registers activity.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (waking) Viljar? VILJAR blinks, shifting in and out of consciousness. CHRISTIN (CONT’D) Viljar can you hear me? SVEINN wakes. He and TORJE staring at VILJAR. CHRISTIN (CONT’D) Get the doctor! VILJAR'S eye flickers again. He looks like he’s trying to speak. CHRISTIN (CONT’D) (as Sveinn goes) Viljar! Doctors arrive and begin checks.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD SURGEON
dialogues.text: Can you try and move your left arm for me, Viljar? VILJAR'’s arm shifts a little.  133 134 71. LEAD SURGEON (CONT’D) * That’s great. Can you tell me where * you live, Viljar? * Anxious moments, while VILJAR tries to remember. Tries to form the words.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Svalbard. *

dialogues.speaker: TRAUMA SURGEON
dialogues.text: That’s very good Viljar, well done. Relief fills the room. He has memory. VILJAR slips back unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot over Oslo.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S ICU ROOM - EARLY MORNING As the sun rises, VILJAR wakes again. He’s highly medicat

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: What happened? CHRISTIN looks at SVEINN, not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: (stepping in) It was a terrorist attack. (beat) You were shot Viljar.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Is Torje OK? *

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: I’m here. *

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: He’s fine, he’s absolutely fine. *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: There was so much shooting. *  135 72.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: There was just one man. Some kind of Right wing extremist. VILJAR processes. His mind moving slowly with the drugs.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: How many did he kill?
(beat) Anders and Simon are dead, Viljar. I’m so sorry. VILJAR begins to cry. Desperate moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD leaving the courthouse through a scrum of JOURNALISTS, CAMERAS, lights. The strain obvious on his f

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (as he walks down the street) I have just informed the court that I will be entering a plea of insanity on behalf of Mr. Breivik. Psychiatric assessments will begin tomorrow. A barrage of flashing lights and questions.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: How do you think the families will feel, Mr Lippestad? LIPPESTAD pushes through as the questions continue.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I can only imagine what they’re going through. They have my fullest sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: How do you feel about defending the guy who did this?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I have to defend him. He’s my client. That’s my duty. +e +e

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Mr Lippestad, should people be concerned about you? You defended a Far-Right extremist three years ago...

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I have no connection with any Far- Right organisation, and never have.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: But your Uncle was a member of the Nazi Party in World War Two...

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right but it has nothing to do with me. It was 70 years ago. Please, I’m a lawyer. I believe in a liberal democratic Norway and, like everyone else, I’m just doing my best to help get us through this. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back on the island. Screaming. Panic. Gunfire. A DARK FIGURE holding a gun looms over a clifftop.

dialogues.speaker: HARD CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S NEW ROOM - NIGHT/DAY 137 VILJAR wakes, screaming. His face clenched in pain. Later: his head bandages removed to reveal the scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR awake, his PARENTS by his side.

dialogues.speaker: LEAD SURGEON
dialogues.text: It’s going to be a long recovery. Two years. Or three years. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LEAD SURGEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is of course damage to the brain and the bullet fragments that are close to the brain stem could shift at any time. I’m afraid that could be fatal. CHRISTIN holds VILJAR’S hand tight. LEAD SURGEON (CONT’D) We're going to have to take it one day at a time. Your life will be very different now. On VILJAR, taking this in. LEAD SURGEON (CONT’D) Do you want to ask me anything?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viljar is wheeled back to his room.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Can you give me a minute?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. CHRISTIN and SVEINN leave the room. 74.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 139 See VILJAR, alone. The pain, the fear, the shock. His fuc up body. Hitting him all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK chained like Hannibal Lector.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 140 LIPPESTAD introduces two psychiatrists: DR HUSBY and DR SORHEIM.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (seeing the restraints) Is it necessary to restrain my client?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SORHEIM
dialogues.text: For the moment.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I imagine every psychiatrist in the world envies you right now.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SORHEIM
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Because I am The Monster. And you get to look inside my head.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SORHEIM
dialogues.text: Do you believe you are a monster?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: No. But I know that you do.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUSBY
dialogues.text: You know what I’m thinking?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I always do. Within 70% of accuracy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUSBY
dialogues.text: Do you know or do you think you know?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I know. And there’s a difference.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUSBY
dialogues.text: Do you think people can read your mind?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Sometimes. I think they try.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HUSBY
dialogues.text: Did you feel like that before the attacks, or is it a new feeling?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: It’s not new. But it got worse when I was planning the attacks.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SORHEIM
dialogues.text: Worse?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Much worse. 76. See LIPPESTAD watched BREIVIK. Wonders if this is all an OMITTED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR in his hospital bed. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Hi. What are you doing around here? A moment.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I live around here. We’re checking on survivors. How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m OK. (recognises her) So you made it off the island OK?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was in the shower block when it started. I managed to run and hide. (beat) But I got separated from my sister Bano. She didn’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah... I’m sorry about Simon and Anders too. You were really close, right?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah we were. It’s shit.

dialogues.speaker: 140A
dialogues.text: 141  77. It sits there. Survival is a strange land for both of the

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: How’s the food here? *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: That’s shit too... Actually it’s * really shit. *

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Want me to smuggle you something in? VILJAR shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No, I’m fine. I don’t have much appetite.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Nice...Except I don’t smoke. * He laughs. The first time since the attack. But then pain puts his right hand to his head.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Does it hurt to laugh? *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No, it’s just, I have to be * careful.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: It’s going to take time.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s what everyone keeps * saying.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s what they say to me * too. (a moment between them) I'll leave you in peace. But I can * come back if you want? *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Sure. That'd be nice. *  78.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Great. See you. Take care. * And she’s gone - leaving VILJAR alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow LIPPESTAD into the chambers. He looks across at INGA and SVEINN, as the JUDGE enters.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The psychiatric report determines that Mr. Breivik suffers from paranoid schizophrenia and was in a state of psychosis during the attacks and throughout observation. They recommend treatment in a secure facility.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: (standing) Your Honour, the Prosecution will accept this diagnosis.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Honour. * See LIPPESTAD. A first victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD watching BREIVIK reading his psychiatric report

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: This is only the diagnosis. It will be up to the court whether to accept it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hands him a bundle of newspapers, letters) In the meantime, the judge has modified the terms of your detention. BREIVIK scans the headlines - furious denunciations of hi insanity plea. Opens the letters. Death threats.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: And I will be allowed to speak at the trial?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: This hasn’t been decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: It’s very important. (hands LIPPESTAD a list) There are witnesses I need to cross- examine. LIPPESTAD scans a who’s-who of Norway, starting with the King. Then the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Anders, you can’t call the Prime Minister. Norway isn’t on trial. You are.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Are you sure about that? See LIPPESTAD, as the sounds of a crowd builds.

dialogues.speaker: MOVED TO 149B. 147
dialogues.text: 148 MOVED to 149A. 148 149 INT. PM’S RESIDENCY - NIGHT 149 The PM and his AIDES enter the hallway. Through the window, the PM sees the waiting press outside

dialogues.speaker: AIDE OYSTEIN
dialogues.text: You're going to get questions about Breivik’s insanity plea. There's a lot of anger out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e
See PM. He nods as he puts on his coat. Straightens his t

dialogues.speaker: AIDE MARIT
dialogues.text: We should be prepared for the possibility that he doesn’t go prison. PM picks up his bag.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE OYSTEIN
dialogues.text: to You're going to have to address the elections too.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: I understand. Thank you. PM exits through the main door to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PM emerges to... Flashlights. A waiting PRESS POOL, and a

dialogues.speaker: 149A
dialogues.text: lobby of questions:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Prime Minister! Any comment on Mr Breivik’s insanity plea?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Is Breivik making a mockery of justice, Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: How do you respond to ordinary Norwegians who think Mr. Breivik should be made accountable for his actions?

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: Like all Norwegians, I'm following the legal proceedings closely, but it would be inappropriate for me, as Prime Minister, to comment on an on-going court case.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: What about the elections, Prime Minister? Are you going to postpone them? +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: The elections will go ahead as scheduled. It is important that our democratic process continues as normal.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Do you honestly feel we can have elections so soon after the attacks? When there is so much anger?

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: We're being tested as never before. In our courts. In our hearts, and in our minds. We have to trust our system. Trust that it will find a way to bring us through safely. Together. And I believe it will. The PM gets into his waiting car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP of LAWYERS, led by FAMILY LAWYER (female, 40s) ME LARSEN, walk towards court through a crowd of JOURNALISTS

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Ms Larsen, how do the families feel about Breivik’s insanity plea?

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: I can say on behalf of my clients, that they strongly oppose Mr. Breivik’s psychiatric diagnosis, and as the coordinating lawyer for the families and survivors of the 22nd July attacks, I will be petitioning the court today to order further assessments. We demand that Mr. Breivik face justice and be held accountable for his actions. Flurry of flashlights. OMITTED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 152 82. INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S NEW ROOM - DAY 151 A NURSE carefully removes VILJAR’S bandages on his should Revealing angry red wounds. CHRISTIN watches. Sees VILJAR in pain.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (to nurse) Can we get him something for the-

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No. No more morphine. LATER: CHRISTIN feeds VILJAR. Dabs his mouth with a cloth VILJAR silent, submissive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIN pushes VILJAR in the wheelchair. Her phone rings. She turns it onto silent.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: How’s the campaign going?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: People are angry.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t you be there?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: So how does that work on election night?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: I can Skype.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Skype? Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, Skype. Maybe you could Skype with me? If you’re up to it...

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Only if you win...

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (the first time she’s seen him smile) I’ll try. Her phone goes again.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Take it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l call them later.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: It’s a fucking election. Take it. A moment between them. She takes the call, leaving VILJAR. He looks around, uncertain in the BUSY corridor. Then he hears the sound o TV. Wheels towards it...

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORT
dialogues.text: ...-Norwegians are convinced Breivik is trying to cheat justice, and have reacted with an outpouring of national anger.

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN VOX POP
dialogues.text: He kills 77 people and doesn’t go to jail? It makes me ashamed to be Norwegian.

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN VOX POP 2
dialogues.text: I feel so sorry for those parents. The thought of him walking the street...

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: The families have made their submissions to the court, in the strongest terms. We oppose Mr. Breivik’s insanity plea, and we await the court’s decision. VILJAR turns a corner. Comes face-to-face with BREIVIK on TV.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORT
dialogues.text: (over footage of Breivik led into courtroom) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile Breivik’s trial has been set for 16th April...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunfire. Running. Screaming. And that DARK FIGURE looming over the clifftop.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN, (0.0.V)
dialogues.text: Viljar!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (bringing him back to reality) Viljar! See VILJAR. Battling fear and rage. CHRISTIN (CONT’D) He can’t get you. He’s never going to get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PM watching election results. Alone. The mood is somb The Labour Party retain power, but the Right have made striking gains across the country.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: ...there is no question Norway is following the European trend. Hard- line right-wing parties are growing in strength... and the question has to be asked, are people losing faith in the system? Are they beginning to give up on democracy? Hold on the PM.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: +e  156 157 85. INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S NEW ROOM - NIGHT 156 CHRISTIN on her laptop. Her family around her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (to Skype camera) I’m honoured to become Mayor of Svalbard, and I want to thank everyone for being so understanding. It’s been a difficult time, but hopefully we will be home soon. (beat) Oh and Viljar has a message. She adjusts the computer.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (this is difficult) Hi, everybody! Hope you can hear me? And I don’t look too scary! (he struggles, then) I’m very proud of my mum. Hopefully they’11 let me out of this place soon and we'll all get home for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (steps in) So tonight we're going to have a little celebration here in the hospital. And in the morning I'11l get to work, because we have so much to do to heal our country. She ends the call. The room subdued, the whole family strangely empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR trying to stand. A PHYSIOTHERAPIST assisting. His hand pushes down hard into the bench. His legs shake as h forces his body up.

dialogues.speaker: PHSYIO
dialogues.text: Steady... VILJAR takes a step. Then his legs buckle. He shouts out pain. The PHYSIO catches him.  158 Close on VILJAR, all energy spent, angry and afraid.
158 VILJAR walking slowly with a frame. Managing the pain as he can. Lara next to him.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m so fucking helpless. I mean look at me. I can barely walk. I can’t eat on my own. I can’t piss without being terrified. (beat) It makes me so fucking angry.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: You want to stop?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Go slowly...

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: And I get flashbacks.. Do you get the fucking flashbacks?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I had one yesterday. Some people across the street started to run. For a bus or something completely ordinary. But I started to run too. I don’t know why, but I felt like he was right behind me, over my shoulder, he was this big...

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (interrupting) 20-foot high. With a huge gun. Just fucking huge. High above you, right?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Exactly... (beat) I just kept running.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: That’s easy for you to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Right! Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No, it’s OK - you want to race? They laugh. Later: they sit in the hospital cafe. VILJAR looks over to a newspaper picture of BREIVIK.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're saying he’s insane. Do you think he’s insane?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I saw him like This close. (beat) He knew what he was doing. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? When you get out?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I can’t see the future. It’s like I’m still there on the rocks. Like I’m out there in no man’s land. Do you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. But we survived. Right?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah. But what does that even mean? See VILJAR’s doubt.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I really don’t know... That we have to try to live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK in his cell...

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. COURTHOUSE
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD up the front steps. Looking concerned. We follo him into the chambers. He sees the Prosecution lawyers INGA and SVEINN. And FAMI LAWYER. The JUDGE enters.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARTNZEN
dialogues.text: After careful consideration the Court has decided to allow further psychiatric assessment of Mr. Breivik. (sees LARSEN stand) Yes, Ms. Larsen?

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Your Honour, the families welcome this decision. And they thank you. We will call our own psychiatric experts to give evidence in the trial.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (standing) Your Honour, the court has already had Mr. Breivik psychiatrically examined. Allowing further assessment has no precedent in law.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARTNZEN
dialogues.text: Mr, Lippestad, the court is trying to do what’s best for Norway. See LIPPESTAD. This is a reverse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD watching BREIVIK reading the Court’s judgement.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Why are they doing this? +e +e +e  161 162 89.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: They want you to answer for what you did.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: But this is my trial.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Victims have rights too. They have to be able to call their witnesses and testify, just as you can. It’s their right, Anders. Hold on BREIVIK, angry at being checked for the first tim

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ULLEVAL HOSPITAL - VILJAR’S NEW ROOM - DAY 161 VILJAR packing his things into a bag (now with a stick). Sudden silent shards of memory: ANDERS and SIMON’s faces, laughing as they unpack by their tents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARA watches from the curb, as VILJAR is helped into the of a people-carrier. He sits next to TORJE. TORJE quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Hi! I wanted to see you off. Will you be alright?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s gonna be good to get home. What about you? Will you be

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Yep. I’ll be fine. I have to look for a job to keep myself busy, so I don’t think about things. SVEINN walks over to them.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again. +e

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: You too. (to VILJAR) I’1l call you.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Sure. CHRISTIN comes up and says goodbye to LARA. Viljar gets i back of the van.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: We'll have that race when you get back to Oslo then.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m going to do some serious training and then I’1l1 beat you! CHRISTIN closes the door and gets into the car. LARA watches the car pull away.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 163
dialogues.text: A remote island in the ARCTIC SEA. 2000km from OSLO. Snow mountain wilderness. A kind of Eden.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HANSSEN CAR — CONTINUOUS 163A VILJAR and FAMILY drive towards the small community of Longyearbyen.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT/INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - DAY 164 They pull up outside a small clapper-board home. A snow- mobile parked outside. VILJAR gets out of the car. He struggles to walk. They enter and CHRISTIN helps VI1JAR with his coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Do you want me to...

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Be careful. +e

TORJE goes ahead of him to his bedroom and shuts the door SVEINN takes the cases upstairs. Alone in his bedroom, VILJAR sees the life he once had. Smiling photos with his friends, his Arsenal posters, his skis.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Do you want me to help with your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No, I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Meanwhile upstairs, CHRISTIN unpacks. SVEINN can feel her tension. He catches her. She stifles tears.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: Breath with me. In - out. She breaths deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORJE in his bedroom, headphones on. VILJAR in his bedroom, sees a car approach. A knock at the front door. CHRISTIN answers it. SIMON and ANDERS’ PARENTS, last seen at the hotel. A terrible moment. SIMON’S FATHER (holds out a bottle) Simon and Anders would have wanted us to welcome you home.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. They embrace. Conflicted in grief and love.

dialogues.speaker: 166C
dialogues.text: INT. ILA PRISON - BREIVIK’S CELL - DAY BREIVIK angrily pacing. Deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establisher of playschool. KIDS play outside.

dialogues.speaker: 166B
dialogues.text: SIGNE and LIPPESTAD in a meeting with HEADMISTRESS.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: There have been complaints. From parents. Because you’re defending such a dangerous man.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: They're worried about the school being targeted. HEADMISTRESS (CONT’D) It's a very difficult time. We have to think about what’s best for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNE
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. But you need to find another school.

dialogues.speaker: 166C
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD and SIGNE leaving the school, with their DAUGHT +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: SIGNE
dialogues.text: There’s Frogner down by the museum. At least it’s nearer.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Is it good?

dialogues.speaker: SIGNE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. It wasn’t the one we chose. (suddenly she breaks down) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. LIPPESTAD holds her. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD is led by a GUARD down the corridor... INT. ILA PRISON —- HOLDING ROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I want to change my plea. I’m not insane.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (hasn't seen this coming) But you agreed to this defense. The psychiatric assessment said you were ill.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I was playing a role. I was playing the monster in a nightmare. But I’m not a monster. I’m a soldier ina war, doing my duty. A leader. And a leader does not give away his power. I’ve allowed the families to take control, but this is my trial. I decide how it ends. I have to prove these attacks meant something. (beat) And I need to be judged for what I did. 167

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: You'll go to prison. For the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I have to finish what I started. Standing up in the court. I have to stand up for what I believe in. That’s the third attack. That’s the whole point of this. That is how I win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD walks away from the prison.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIPPESTAD’S OFFICE - DAY 170 Piles of files across every surface. LIPPESTAD looks tire

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (to his TEAM) He wants to change his defense. He wants to plead guilty.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD ASSISTANT 1
dialogues.text: Has he given any reason? I mean, why?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: He wants to stay in control.

dialogues.speaker: VIBEKE DEF LAWYER
dialogues.text: And he knows the consequences?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: He wants to stand up and be accountable for his actions.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD ASSISTANT 2
dialogues.text: It’s going to be very hard. The psychiatric assessment was clear. He’s been diagnosed insane. And the Prosecution are legally obliged to stick with it. So how do we get around that? a

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Ok so we have to start again. To show that he knew what he was doing. Every step of the way. That only someone rational could have planned and executed something this complex. And we have to look into the Far-Right. Find witnesses who share his beliefs. So we can show that he’s not alone in his views. That’s the only way we can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot of Longyearbyen. Hemmed in by mountains on one side, and the Arctic Sea on other. A pick-up pulls up at a remote building. SVEINN gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIN in her new office with her TEAM.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (to the group) We need to generate new ideas. New ways of bringing investment back into the local economy. Coal prices are falling. We can’t rely on the mines anymore. Fishing too. It’s up to us to look for new ways to secure Svalbard’s future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 173 174 175 96. INT. SVEINN’S OFFICE - DAY 172C SVEINN in his more spartan office space. A couple of computers. Science equipment, outdoor gear, charts tracki migration patterns across the Arctic Sea. See SVEINN, trying to engage with his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR lying in an MRI tunnel. The screen showing his dam brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EYE DOCTOR carefully fits a prosthetic eye into VILJAR empty socket. Bright blue, but lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR, (0.0.V)
dialogues.text: How are you Viljar?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD HOSPITAL - DOCTOR’S ROOM - DAY 175 VILJAR in front of a SECOND DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (he shrugs) My head hurts. All the time. And my shoulder. (beat) I get phantom pain...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: That’s natural. See VILJAR, it doesn’t feel natural to him. SECOND DOCTOR (CONT’D) This is going to be a long recovery, Viljar. The bullet fragments are less than a tenth of a millimeter from the major nerve centres in your brain. The slightest movement-

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (cuts him off) I know what the fucking dangers are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR walking painfully back from the hospital. A sudden noise - he flinches, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’'S HOME - BATHROOM - DAY 176 Close up in a mirror: VILJAR, topless, looks at his false eye. The red scars across his skull, shoulder. His deform hand. In the background: BREIVIK is on TV. Dominating the headlines. Holding the country to ransom. Hold on VILJAR. No escape. As we track in, we feel his an rising. He punches the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR slewing his snow mobile down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. VILJAR’S HOME - SAME TIME 176B TORJE runs up the stairs

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: Mum, Dad! CHRISTIN and SVEINN look out the window. See VILJAR speed away. They run down to the pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POV at speed through dense snow. VILJAR on the snow mobile. Riding hard. Back to the POV again: Round a bend. See Viljar pushing on. Faster, faster. As if daring to cr Now lights behind... SVEINN and CHRISTIN coming after him in a pick-up. Desperate to catch him. VILJAR turns a sharp bend. Faster still. Another bend. An another. See VILJAR, closing on the trees. Closing, closing... unt at the last minute he ploughs into a soft snow drift.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: (out of the pickup) Viljar!! He and CHRISTIN run over to him. VILJAR walking away.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I can’t live like this! Thinking I’m going to get better. I’m not. It’s all still here. In my head. I can’t get rid of it. They get closer. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck am I supposed to do? Tell me! Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I wish it had been me not you. This lands.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (hugs him) It’s OK. Let’s go home, OK.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIPPESTAD’S HOME - NIGHT 180 LIPPESTAD searches Far-Right forums online: Fascism, raci violence. Ancient hatreds spewing out of his computer, pouring out across Europe, across the world. See SIGNE watching, heavily pregnant, her unease impossib to hide.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. EAST OSLO - EXTREMIST’ HOUSE - DAY 181 A part of Oslo we haven’t seen before. Poorer, harsher. Neglected. LIPPESTAD parks outside a block of flats. A huddle of MUS MEN on chairs outside a corner shop. LIPPESTAD heads for a tower block. Sees Far-Right graffit The Norwegian flag. KIDS faces through the windows. He enters the block and gets into lift. Doors close.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. EAST OLSO —- EXTREMIST’S APARTMENT - DAY 182 LIPPESTAD sits in front of a white man (40s).

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: My client Anders Breivik writes about you in his manifesto. He obviously admires you.

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Many people admire me. But it’s not me they admire. It’s my ideas about the world.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Did you ever meet him?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: He asked. But I’m careful who I work with. What I do, who I meet. (beat) He’s not from round here you know. He’s from your end of town. But yes, we share the same vision for the world.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: He says a war is coming.

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: I'd say it’s already started...

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Are you a member of the Knight’s Templar?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: There are many other organisations.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: The Nordic Resistance Movement?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: All across Scandinavia. Northern Europe. We're strong in eastern Europe too of course. Very strong in the UK too. New groups forming all the time.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: How about America?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Stormfront. Growing fast. Very fast. And joining up with us here in Europe.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: How do you communicate?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Where you can’t see us. In chat rooms. The Dark Web. Lippestad, with every al-Qaeda attack, we grow in strength. Every migrant boat that crosses the Med, more people join. There’s a lot of fear and anger out there... And that’s why, tomorrow will belong to us. That hangs there.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Will you testify in my client’s defense?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED. 186
dialogues.text: 187 INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - KITCHEN - DAY 187 CHRISTIN receives an email. Her expression changes. Goes downstairs. Puts on coat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (seeing VILJAR) You OK?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: I’m just going to see your father. VILJAR watches his MOTHER drive away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 187A EXT. SVALBARD - SVEINN’S OFFICE - DAY 187A SVEINN tagging birds in cages, 400m from his office. CHRISTIN arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: We just got an email. From the lawyers. There’s a briefing on the mainland. They want us to go. So we know what to expect from the trial.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: You should go.  188 189 102.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Sveinn.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: We both need to engage with this. It’s important.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: Engaging nearly cost our sons their lives.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: They're still here.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: Are they? (beat) I don’t care about him. I don’t care about Anders fucking Breivik and his trial. And I just want us to get on with our lives. That’s all. Just that. We’ve got them home. I just want our boys back. And I don’t want any trial stopping it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY 188 VILJAR alone. On TV: relentless coverage of Breivik’s imminent trial. He turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - DAY 18 VILJAR outside Torje’s closed door. Loud music from insid

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Torje? (no answer) I’m going into town. Do you want to come?  190 191 103. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR walking slowly along Longyearbyen’s main street. FAMILIES, KIDS. A festive atmosphere. The sun is about to return. VILJAR walks on, head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR at a table alone. Watching STUDENTS on the street outside, laughing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Viljar! The voice is on Viljar’s blind side. Panic. And then he s SIMON’S FATHER.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry. I didn’t see you. SIMON’S FATHER That’s OK. I don’t want to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: It’s fine. SIMON’S FATHER How are you?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m OK. It’s taking a while. You know... I’m sorry. I meant to visit. How are you? How’s Tone? SIMON’S FATHER It’s tough.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah.  104. SIMON’S FATHER Listen, we're going ice-fishing this weekend. To Simon’s spot. * Would you like to come? There’s * plenty of room in the cabin. *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Thanks... I.. Can I let you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMON’S FATHER Sure. He looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Sorry. I will come. I’m just... * It’s just a bit... * SIMON’S FATHER It’s OK. I understand. Viljar stands, painfully.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Sorry. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR lying on the rocks, bleeding out.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Simon? No reply. Only distant gunfire. Muffled cries of pain on wind.

dialogues.speaker: HARD CUT TO
dialogues.text: 192 INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - LATER 192 VILJAR closes the front door behind him. * Sees TORJE at the end of the corridor. *

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: Hey

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Do you want to watch a movie or something?

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: Sure. Maybe later. I’m just doing some music.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: TORJE goes into his room. Closes his door. VILJAR goes to TORJE’s door.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Torje, talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No you’re not. You know you can talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: I don’t need to. You’re the one who got hurt, not me.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: You were there too. See TORJE, remembering the island.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry that Mum and Dad have been looking after me so much. But we're home now. It’s going to be OK. It hangs there. VILJAR walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow CHRISTIN towards a room, crowded with PARENTS and their LAWYERS. She pauses outside. Hears a loud argument progress. She opens the door and slips into the back as t argument rages.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 1
dialogues.text: I just don’t see how it can be right that he’s allowed to speak. My daughter can’t leave her bedroom because of him. He broke her, and now he gets to stand up there and tell us how he did it.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: The court has to observe his rights.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 1
dialogues.text: But he doesn’t deserve rights!

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 2
dialogues.text: He’s trying to use this trial as a platform for his propaganda.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: I will be there to ensure that doesn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 2
dialogues.text: But it is happening. That’s exactly what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Look, the judge is letting us bring our own psychiatric experts, and we're closing the trial with victim impact statements-

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 3
dialogues.text: They should just hang him.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Listen, I promise you, we will have our chance to-

dialogues.speaker: PARENT 3
dialogues.text: But it’s not enough! This isn’t justice! They should just string him up. Be done with it. See CHRISTIN. Finally she can’t take it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: (to everyone) Our children won't get justice by executing him. (beat) I know you’re angry. I’m angry too. And my sons came back. Many of your children didn’t. But we can’t surrender to our anger, no matter how much we feel it. Somehow we have to learn to trust the world again. To trust each other. We have to reconnect. And that begins when we walk into that courtroom. (beat) Our power will come from how we respond to this man. Not in how we silence him. We have to trust in justice. That’s the only way we'll win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIN by her car. She hands

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Christin! CHRISTIN a letter. FAMILY LAWYER (CONT’D) Would you mind giving this to Viljar? (beat) I would like him to testify, if you think he’s up to it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: I'll give it to him.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR walks away from the house. Opens the envelope. Rea + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN, (OOV)
dialogues.text: They want him to testify... *

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 197 INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - LATER 1 Angle on VILJAR out of the window. TV on in living room.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t have to do it. We can get the doctor to excuse him.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Maybe he needs to. *

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: What does that mean? *

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Maybe he needs to face it. *

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: How do we know it won’t set him back?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: We don’t. It’s his choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR gets out phone and dials. * LARA’S VOICE Viljar?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Hey. LARA’S VOICE I was worried about you. *

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m fine... (beat) I just received a letter. They want me to appear. At the trial.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Me too. On Viljar, flash of relief.

dialogues.speaker: LARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think you can face him? Suddenly we’re back on the island. Gunfire. Screaming. An the DARK FIGURE looming above. LARA’S VOICE Viljar? VILJAR forces himself back.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m here. LARA’S VOICE I said, do you think you can do it?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I can’t even walk down the fucking street.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Maybe we need to try.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah... I need to think about it. I’ll call you later. Bye. LARA’S VOICE Bye. See VILJAR alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oslo at sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breivik’s white van convoy leaves through the prison gate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGRY CROWDS mass behind barriers. ARMED POLICE, SNIFFER DOGS. And the world’s MEDIA too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow LIPPESTAD into the empty courtroom. A moment on hi own. Then the prosecution lawyers, INGA and SVEINN enter. Then FAMILY LAWYER and her team. The soft shuffle of legal papers, as we hear the gatherin sound of an angry roar outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK arrives through a gauntlet of rage. Into the underground car park... *

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’ HOME - SAME TIME 205 * VILJAR turns on the TV. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns on the TV. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breivik is led up through the building...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD waits for Breivik to arrive. The courtroom is crowded. Banks of PRESS and CAMERAS. Broadcasting live. H looks to his right: PARENTS, just a few feet away. Those had argued with CHRISTIN. A ripple through the room as BREIVIK enters. LIPPESTAD watches as he is uncuffed. Turns to face the crowded courtroom. Looks at the parents. Going from face- face. Then turns and punches the air with a Nazi salute. The room recoils with shock. Cameras click. See LIPPESTAD, he knows the third attack is a call to arm

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - CONTINUOUS 208 VILJAR watches Breivik’s salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE nods to the Prosecution.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: (stands ) On 22 July 2011, Anders Behring Breivik carried out a dual terror attack taking the lives of 77 innocent people. Hundreds more were injured and left forever scarred by his actions. The facts are clear. First the car bomb, then the mass shooting. There is over-whelming evidence, including his own signed confession. (pauses ) So the question is not whether he committed the crime, the question is how should he be judged? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: INGA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Your Honour, the law is clear. If there is any doubt about the sanity of a person accused, we are required by law to request treatment. Not imprisonment. LIPPESTAD watches the PARENTS, as they impassively listen

dialogues.speaker: INGA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Given the court-ordered, psychiatric diagnosis, the Prosecution believes there is clearly significant doubt as to Anders Behring Breivik’s state of mind on 22nd July. Therefore, we request the court to find him guilty, but sentence him to mandatory psychiatric treatment in a secure facility. INGA sits. The JUDGE nods to LIPPESTAD.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (standing) Your Honour, we will not seek to deny the crimes committed on July 22nd. However, we will argue that Mr. Breivik was not psychotic during these attacks. Instead, we say he knew exactly what he was doing. (feels Breivik’s eyes on him) And though it is difficult to comprehend Anders Breivik’s view of the world, we will show that he is not alone in his opinions. There are others who think the way he does. Increasing numbers of people, all over the west. His were political acts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK performs another Nazi salute.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (his opening statement) I stand here today on behalf of Europeans who are being deprived of their ethnic, indigenous, cultural, and territorial rights. (beat) The Prosecution tell you I am insane. They do this because they fear me. Because I have committed the most sophisticated, the most spectacular, political assassination in Europe since World War Two. (beat, he turns a page) And why? Because Norway, Europe. These are not real democracies. Is it democratic for a nation not to be consulted about whether it becomes multicultural? To fail to ask your people for permission before welcoming immigrants? To force them to become a minority in their own capital? There can be no democracy whilst the liberal elites in Europe are in power. Democratic struggle is pointless. Many will realise this in the coming decades and pick up arms. Just as I did. He turns the page. Family lawyer LARSEN stands to object.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: The Defendant has said enough, Your Honour.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARTNZEN
dialogues.text: You must hurry up, Mr. Breivik.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I must be allowed to finish my statement!

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: This is extremely upsetting for the families.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (stands ) Your Honour, the Defendant must be allowed to finish his statement.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARTNZEN
dialogues.text: (beat) You may continue, Mr. Breivik. LIPPESTAD sits uncomfortable. Aware of the parents gaze. FEW walk out in protest. But MOST remain. Impassive.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: When peaceful revolution is made impossible, then violent revolution is the only option. LIPPESTAD looks at the PARENTS. Their anger and their powerful dignity. Feels the shame of his position.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I demand to be acquitted because I acted in defense of my country.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME —- CONTINUOUS 213A Track in on VILJAR. As he watches the end of BREIVIK’s testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR at the edge of an empty gymnasium. He drops his st walks out towards the middle, unaided. Half-way he stops. Unsteady on his feet. See the effort on his face.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (turns to SVALBARD DOCTOR by the door) I've got eight weeks. I want to walk unassisted. No stick. No shaking. No breathlessness.

dialogues.speaker: SVALBARD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Viljar, you’re still very weak. +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Just tell me what I need to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PM’s car pulls into the basement of the anonymous government building.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. INQUIRY HQ - INTERVIEW ROOM —- CONTINUOUS 215 The PM sits alone in front of the Inquiry panel, STAFF at tables to one side.

dialogues.speaker: GJIORV
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming today, Prime Minister. (beat) I want to begin by exploring to what extent Government was aware of the threat posed by Anders Behring Breivik prior to his attacks on 22nd July.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: The Security Services told me they had no warnings. He operated completely out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: GJORV
dialogues.text: He could not have been detected in advance?

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: That is my understanding. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GJORV
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, our investigation has discovered that Mr. Breivik’s purchase of chemicals used in the preparation of the bomb came to the attention of the customs service in January 2011. But this was not acted upon by the Security Services.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: That is not what I was told, Madam Chair.

dialogues.speaker: GJORV
dialogues.text: Can we turn now to the issue of physical security around the Government Quarter itself. (beat) It appears from the papers there were proposals discussed inside government to improve physical security around the Prime Minister’s Office. The PM reads.

dialogues.speaker: GJIORV
dialogues.text: Were you aware of these discussions?

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: In general terms. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GJORV
dialogues.text: So can I ask you why Government did not act?

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: There were delays. Concerns that Oslo’s city centre would become a closed area. We did not want our Government cut off from the people. (Beat) It was a mistake. Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: GIGRV
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: (beat) If mistakes were made, they were made in good faith. In the most difficult circumstances. And I take full responsibility for any and all failings. That’s all I can say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass windows we see the PM silently continui his testimony.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Mr Breivik, can I ask you about the Knights Templar? Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: The Knights Templar are a network. Patriots, who think the way I do and are willing take up arms just as I did, in order to defend their way of life.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: How big is this network?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: We have members in every country. All across the West.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Mr. Breivik, you told police that this organisation was set up in London in 2002. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Yes. After 9/11.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Did you attend this first meeting?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: And what happened?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I was given my mission. This mission.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: I see. Why did they pick you?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Well don’t forget, I was a key figure in the student parliament, at school. LAUGHTER in the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + + +e HF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Mr. Breivik, the police have tracked your movements in 2002 and found no evidence that you attended such a meeting. Can you explain this?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: It was a covert meeting.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: But now it is no longer a secret, can you prove this meeting actually took place?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Can you tell me the names of those who attended the meeting?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: The names of anyone in the Knights Templar?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I will not betray my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Mr. Breivik, it will help your case if you can give us some, any, evidence that the Knights Templar actually exists.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (with steel) Here is the problem in society today. Clearly exposed. You say I am mad because I tell you many people out there think and feel as I do. About immigrants. About multiculturalism. But is it my madness or are you, the liberal elites, so out of touch that you don’t want to hear what we are saying? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what does it say about you, that rather than listen, you call mad, those of us with whom you disagree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR in physio. Sweating hard. Battling the pain. The PHYSIO watching from afar. Looking concerned.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO REPORTER, (OOV)
dialogues.text: There is no doubt that Anders Breivik is in control. He’s using the trial for his own purposes... Finally VILJAR’s legs buckle. VILJAR on his hands and knees. Pushes himself up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD is cross-examining BREIVIK now.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Mr Breivik, can you describe your preparations for the attacks?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: I was meticulous. First, I sold my assets. Then I carefully began to assemble the components of the bomb. I did it very slowly of course, so the authorities wouldn’t see me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Can you give me an example?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Yes. A component of the bomb is found in aspirin tablets. I knew it would raise red flags if I attempted to buy too many packs at one time. So I created a purchasing route, which covered twenty drug- stores. It took me four hours to complete. On foot. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e + eH HH  220

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I then waited seven to fourteen days before I began the route again. Month after month. Two packs at a time. I was very careful.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Would you say you can feel empathy?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m a normal person. I’m sane. There is a distinction between political extremism and insanity. They are very different things. (beat) However, I needed a lot of mental preparation for this mission. I knew these attacks would be highly violent. There was a risk that, through empathy, I might lose my nerve. So I learned an ancient form of meditation. To control my emotions. I used it during the attacks, and I’m using it right now. (beat) Shall I make this easier for you all? I will forego any appeal, any re-trial, spare the families all for this, if the court finds me sane. On LIPPESTAD, watching BREIVIK holding the justice system hostage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR training hard. Pushing himself to the point of failing. But he’s a long way away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR alone. Shattered. CHRISTIN and SVEINN come in. +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally: 121.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (seeing them) I’m not ready.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do it. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: It’s not okay. I need to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: Then don’t push yourself so hard. Just say a few words. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: And say what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: What happened. The truth.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: What that I cry in my sleep? That I can’t talk to strangers? That I’m frightened of dying? I'd rather not go than let him hear that.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTIN
dialogues.text: The truth doesn’t make you weak.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: It doesn't make me feel strong.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: What is it you want?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I want to smash him. Smash him to a bloody pulp. Smash his face in. For what he did to everyone. To Simon and Anders, and Torje, and you. I want to make him see what he’s done and what it’s meant. I just want to beat him.

dialogues.speaker: SVEINN
dialogues.text: Well then this is your chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD cross-examines the FAR-RIGHT EXTREMIST. BREIVIK watching closely.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: How long have you been active in the politics of the Far-Right in Norway?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: My whole adult life.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: And you share Mr. Breivik'’s opinions on the subject of immigration?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: And you agree with him that multiculturalism is a threat to Europe?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Are you aware of others who share these opinions?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Many people. I would say millions. Wouldn’t you? See BREIVIK, vindicated.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Have you ever met the Defendant?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: I’ve met him online.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Online?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: In chat forums, attached to mythic, military games like World of Warcraft. Call of Duty. Our movement often congregates there. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a place to train, to share ideas.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Recruit?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: How did the defendant strike you?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: He liked to lead missions online. To strategise.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Was he rational?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Was he a leader?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: He certainly wanted to be.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I have no more questions. INGA stands, to begin the Prosecution’s cross-examination

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Was Mr. Breivik your leader?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t follow Mr. Breivik?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: I think others in our movement are better qualified than him.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Stronger than Mr. Breivik?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: For sure. See LIPPESTAD glance at BREIVIK.  222

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Better than Mr. Breivik?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Would they be capable of doing what Anders Behring Breivik did?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something about our movement. The Alt-Right. The Far- Right. Whatever you want to call us. (beat) We're deadly serious. About seizing power. Changing society completely. About total victory. (beat) Not singular, violent acts that don’t contribute to that goal. The tide of history is flowing our way again. Nothing must get in its way. See BREIVIK watching intently. She waits.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: So I'll repeat the question. Would you, holding your views - the same views as Mr. Breivik - have done what he did?

dialogues.speaker: EXTREMIST
dialogues.text: (a beat) No. I would not. 124. See LIPPESTAD and BREIVIK. For the first time, a flash of real anger on BREIVIK’s face. See the FAMILIES, registering the win.

dialogues.speaker: INGA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD enters. BREIVIK is pacing.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: He’s a coward. He’s a fucking coward.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: He was the best I could get.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: To betray me like that. You never betray a brother. Never. You know I looked up to him. I trusted him. I fucking trusted him.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: There was no-one else.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: There must be someone who can testify.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Anders, there’s no-one who will agree to defend your actions.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: What about my mother? She could say I was normal.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: She won’t do it either. See BREIVIK. This lands.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: She’s weak.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I saw her. She’s not well.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: It’s always about her. Always. Pathetic. Do you know there’s not once when I could rely on her. Not even once. (beat) Okay. I don’t need anyone. I never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD and BREIVIK watch as FAMILY LAWYER cross-examin her first PSYCHIATRIC WITNESS. +e

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Dr. Toov. Please can you outline your qualifications for the court?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PSYCHIATRIC WITNESS
dialogues.text: I’m a Professor of Psychiatry. I have over 30 years of clinical experience. Both here in Norway and abroad. And I have studied carefully the various psychiatric assessments of Mr. Breivik, carried out in prison.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: In your expert opinion, can you give the court your assessment of Mr. Breivik’s state of mind, when he carried out the attacks on the 22 July?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PSYCHIATRIST WITNESS
dialogues.text: It is my opinion that Mr. Breivik suffers from a severe personality disorder. But there is no evidence of clinical psychosis. Of insanity. See BREIVIK, vindicated. FIRST PSYCHIATRIST WITNESS (CONT’D) Of course, Mr. Breivik is a man who lives in a fantasy world. He makes up stories to inflate his own importance. Stories about the Knights Templar, for instance, which clearly does not exist. But these grandiose claims are not delusions. They are lies. Just that. Lies.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: Lies?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PSYCHIATRIST WITNESS
dialogues.text: Yes. Lies about himself and the way the world is. Lies to try to recruit people to his side. To elevate himself out of his own insignificance. Put simply, he lies as a defense mechanism. To make himself appear less of the failure that inside he feels himself to be. LIPPESTAD watching BREIVIK closely. Sees a gathering ange

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH HH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how would you categorise Mr. Breivik?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PSYCHIATRIST WITNESS
dialogues.text: In an attempt to categorise the Defendant, to make sense of him, I believe we are missing the point entirely. The truth is simple. Anders Behring Breivik feels rejected by society. Unloved, ignored, forgotten, and deeply, deeply lonely. And all his overwhelming anger flows from this.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (on his feet) This is offensive!! It’s lies! All lies!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARNTZEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Breivik, please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (finally losing control) I’ve never failed at anything! Not one thing in my entire life! I’m not alone. I have many friends! I have never been rejected!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARNTZEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Lippestad, please ask your client to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (to LIPPESTAD) You have to stop this. You’re my lawyer. You’re supposed to protect me.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: They have the right to do this. To submit their own witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: But they’re filming it.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Yes. This is how the system works.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: But you need to counter it!

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: You’ve had your chance to speak, it’s the turn of the families now. And tomorrow the victims. They have rights too.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: And I have to listen? Just sit here and listen to this?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: If you want to be found sane, you must submit to the system. LIPPESTAD toe-to-toe with BREIVIK. Hold on BREIVIK. Watch by the JUDGE, the PROSECUTION, and the FAMILIES. Finally, relents.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: No more questions, Your Honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD sprints down a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIGNE in labour. A water birth. Pushing through the pain. Delivers her baby. LIPPESTAD at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD being handed his newborn DAUGHTER. His other CHILDREN - including REBEKAH and the AU PAIR - in the roo too.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: She’s beautiful. But then his voice breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR walking up hill. One foot in front of the other. Behind him: the endless snows of Svalbard.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER, (OOV)
dialogues.text: Next we call Lara Rashid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD watches LARA testify to FAMILY LAWYER.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: My big sister Bano and I fled Iraq in 1999. We were refugees. My father brought us to Norway to be safe. When I came from Kurdistan - what you call Irag - I was just five years old. I was a refugee. It took a long time for Norway to feel like home. I struggled with the language. The climate too. And some people were suspicious of us. Angry that we were here. LIPPESTAD looks at BREIVIK. No reaction.

dialogues.speaker: LARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But my sister Bano helped me. To see that in Norway there could be freedom, security, and hope. And that is what I felt around the campfire on Uteya. The night before. (pauses ) But the next day, when we were attacked - when she died - I lost all that. I was suddenly ina different world. Of pain and fear. Anger. (holding back her tears) I felt guilty. All of the time. Why did I live when she died? How do I face my parents now? But most of all, I couldn’t understand why someone would want to kill us. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: LARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why would anyone be frightened of me?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: But now I see things differently. I see that Bano died for a reason. Her life was a celebration. Of multicultural Norway. Proof that it can work. That is why she lived. And that is why she died. (beat) And I am still so proud to be her little sister. LARA looks up. Avoids BREIVIK. Sees her PARENTS watching. Tears in their eyes. LIPPESTAD looks at BREIVIK. He’s not even looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - SAME TIME 231 * VILJAR (watching her testify on the TV) sees it too. Know BREIVIK is still in control, as LARA leaves the witness b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SVEINN and CHRISTIN packing the car. *

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SVALBARD - VILJAR’S HOME - VILJAR’S BEDROOM - CONTIM VILJAR stands alone. Coat on. Comes out into hallway. *

dialogues.speaker: 234D
dialogues.text: 235 236 237 131. TORJE comes out too.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: TORJE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIN and SVEINN wait by the car. Look up to see: VILJAR and TORJE come out. VILJAR ahead. TORJE behind, isolated. They get into the car. Drive away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ILA PRISON - BREIVIK’S CELL - NIGHT 235 BREIVIK sits alone. Track in on him. Feel his malignant force.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. OSLO HOTEL - VILJAR’S ROOM - NIGHT 236 VILJAR in a hotel room. Oslo stretching out below him. He pulls out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR approaches a cafe. Looks inside. Sees LARA.  132. LARA sees him. LATER: And now they’re walking along a street.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Very surreal. Seeing him. You walk in and he’s just there.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: She’d be pleased. Bano. She’d be pleased you did it.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I hope so. I really hope so. (beat) He didn’t react, did he?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: No. He didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’1l be fine.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: It’s nearly over.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: (covering) Yeah. Definitely. (beat) Look I’m sorry I got lost. The last few months. I just got...lost.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: It’s OK. So did I. They lock eyes for a moment. VILJAR looks away. They walk

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: How close is he? I couldn’t tell from the TV.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: (holds her hands apart) He’s close. I mean he’s close. See VILJAR, that’s much closer than he expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops. 133.

dialogues.speaker: LARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can do it. (beat) Do you know what you’re going to say?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’ve tried to think of things, but I get confused. I just don’t want to be weak. That’s all. Not in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: You can be weak and still strong, you know.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I think you can. (beat) It’s just, I don’t want to be stuck. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: I’d better get back.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Sure. See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LARA
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR watches her walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide shot over Oslo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ut@ya Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK wakes. Gets dressed. Is cuffed and led away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. OSLO HOTEL - VILJAR’S ROOM - MORNING 239 VILJAR washing his face. He dresses. Black shirt, tie, suit. His wounds visible as combs his hair. Inserts his glass eye. It’s time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK in armed convoy towards the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VILJAR AND FAMILY, on foot, arrive outside the courthouse SVEINN and CHRISTIN lead VILJAR and TORJE through the CRO See VILJAR, trying to keep his breathing steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD prepares for the session.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BREIVIK moves towards the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAMILY through the atrium. Wait outside the courtroom VILJAR paces the lobby alone. TORJE goes over to him. CHRISTIN and SVEINN watch from afar. A moment between the brothers. A COURT USHER comes over.

dialogues.speaker: COURT USHER
dialogues.text: We're ready for you. A moment between VILJAR and his FAMILY. They hug. And then he leaves behind the COURT USHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIN and SVEINN find their seats. CHRISTIN sees the A PARENTS from before. They nod in support. LARA is there too. The crowded court is ready. The JUDGE motions for the ses to begin. A side door opens and BREIVIK is brought in. CHRISTIN and SVEINN watch BREIVIK as he walks past - with touching distance. He takes his seat next to LIPPESTAD. SVEINN takes hold of CHRISTIN’S hand. The courtroom settles.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: We would like to call Viljar Hanssen. LIPPESTAD watches as the door at the back of the courtroo opens. VILJAR enters. He walks to the witness stand. Concentrating on keeping h breathing steady. His PARENTS watching. LARA too.  136. LIPPESTAD watches VILJAR approach. As he approaches the stand, VILJAR sees BREIVIK. His head down, talking to LIPPESTAD. VILJAR tries to control his shaking hands. Takes the last steps to the stand. Finally locks eyes with BREIVIK. For a moment, VILJAR feels himself going back to the isla The sounds of terror and pain. That dark menacing FIGURE looming above him... He struggles for control. Forces himself not to go there. Holds BREIVIK’S empty stare for the longest moment. FAMILY LAWYER (CONT’D) Can you tell us what happened to you on Uteya, Viljar?

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
