dialogues.text: Yes. He tried to... He tried to kill me. (begins to remember) I remember running away. Trying to find somewhere to hide. Trying to protect my little brother. And I remember being shot. (using his right hand) He shot me here, here, here, here, and finally here. In the eye. Five times. I lay on the beach. I was all alone. In a kind of pain I could never imagine. BREIVIK looks up momentarily. Catches VILJAR’s eye.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY LAWYER
dialogues.text: But you’re here now? VILJAR steels himself, keeping his emotion at bay.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Yes. But everything is different. I’ve had to relearn how to use my body. Learn to walk again, to feed myself again. I have little use of my left arm. I’m blind in one eye - but that’s a relief.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTION
dialogues.text: A relief? +e  137.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR
dialogues.text: Oh yes, a relief. Definitely a relief. (a beat and then) Because at least now I don’t have to look at him. Sudden laughter. Breaking the spell. BREIVIK looks around room. Sees EVERYONE laughing. Can’t help but smile himsel And VILJAR sees it. Knows he’s got through. LIPPESTAD see too.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But of course it’s not that simple, I have a fragment of his bullet lodged in my brain, that could kill me at any time. His voice falters.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I don’t look like the person I used to. My body. It’s broken. Beyond repair. My self-confidence too. And I have pain that never goes away. A beat and then:

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Worst of all, he killed Anders and Simon. My best friends. Stopping them from making their mark on the world. They would have made it a better place. I miss them every day. VILJAR stops, swallowing back his pain, trying to keep control. Head down. EVERYONE watching him. Becoming tearf

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn’t want to cry. I so much didn’t want to cry in front of him. I wanted to be strong. Because I do this for them. So they will not be forgotten. VILJAR looks up, right at BREIVIK. Tears, but an unwaveri stare.  246 138.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When he shot them and left me alone on the beach, I didn’t know if I was living or dying. And I’ve been stuck there ever since. +e On BREIVIK, looking right back at him.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now I realise I’ve got a choice. I still have a family. And friends. And memories. Hopes, dreams, and love. (beat) And he doesn’t. He’s completely alone. He’s going to rot in prison, whereas I... (beat) * I survived and I choose to live. +e And at that moment, BREIVIK looks away. LIPPESTAD sees it And VILJAR sees it too. When BREIVIK looks back, they lock eyes again. VILJAR kno he’s won and BREIVIK knows it too.

dialogues.speaker: VILJAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the JUDGE) I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Do the Defense have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: (standing) No questions. (he turns to VILJAR) Thank you. VILJAR leaves the witness box. Sees LARA as he passes. Out of the courtroom and into the light. LIPPESTAD sees BREIVIK watching them, as VILJAR is embrac by his PARENTS and TORJE.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. MOD - PM’S OFFICE - DAY 246 PM alone, reading through the 22nd July Inquiry Report. T weight of it written into his face.  247 248 139.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: The families are waiting for you, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INQUIRY HEAD GJ@RV comes out to address a waiting bank of PRESS.

dialogues.speaker: GJIORV
dialogues.text: Our conclusions are clear. There were failings on and before the attacks of 22 July. The failure to detect Anders Breivik’s activities at an earlier point. The failure to implement effective physical security measures. The failure to respond swiftly enough to the crisis on Utoya Island...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PM walks towards a closed door. Hesitates before open it. Inside, he sees: BEREAVED PARENTS. Their LAWYERS too. The PM sits amongst them.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: (finally) I’m sorry. His voice breaks.

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should have done better. I should have done better. For a moment there is silence. Then a MOTHER reaches acro the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (takes his hand) I can only speak for myself. (She looks around. Clearly she speaks for many there) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only the terrorist was responsible for what happened on that day. Not you. Only him. * The PM looks up, holds her hand tightly, stunned by her grace.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. COURTROOM - Day 8 - VERDICT - DAY 249 BREIVIK standing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE ARTNZEN
dialogues.text: The court finds Anders Behring Breivik guilty of all charges. And we judge him accountable for his actions. Mr. Breivik is therefore sentenced to indefinite solitary confinement. For as long as he * remains a threat to society. +e LIPPESTAD looks across at his colleagues. INGA and SVEINN the Prosecution. FAMILY LAWYER for the families. And at t JUDGE. Knows they all played their roles, to ensure the system prevailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD drives to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and BREIVIK meet for the last time.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Will you appeal?

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: No, there’s no need. You did a good * job. The job I wanted.  141.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: There are some formalities. My office will send over the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Of course. Do you think you will you visit me?

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: I don’t think so, Anders. BREIVIK hands back documents. Then holds out his hand. LIPPESTAD doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: So I guess we’re done.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Yes. As he reaches the door:

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: Geir, I’d do it all again if I could. LIPPESTAD stops. Turns to face him.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: You didn’t win, Anders. You failed.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: (beat and then) There will be others. To finish what I have started. Norway - Europe - it’s crumbling. It’s over.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: We will stop you.

dialogues.speaker: BREIVIK
dialogues.text: You can’t even see us.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPESTAD
dialogues.text: Well we see you now. And we will beat you. My children, our children... they will beat you. (beat) Goodbye, Anders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 253 254 142. LIPPESTAD leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD walks down the corridor away from the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIPPESTAD exits the prison. Out into the sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ILA PRISON - BREIVIK’S CELL/CORRIDOR - DAY 254 As BREIVIK is led down a windowless corridor and into a silent empty cell. The door closes.
